Award.AwardTitle: Multifunctional Hierarchical Structures Via Holographic Lithography and Block Copolymer Self Assembly

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Top-down and bottom-up are two nanomanufacturing approaches which allow one to achieve nanometer scale structures. Top-down method is approaching its theoretic limits on the feature size that it can offer. In contrast, starting from tailored molecules, bottom-up method such as self assembly can easily reach nanometer feature sizes. One drawback of self assembly, however, is the difficulty to achieve large scale, defect-free structures. Combining the top-down and bottom-up methods in one system can lead to novel hierarchical nanostructures with small feature size and less defects. The PI aims to fabricate hierarchically ordered nanostructures (from a few nanometers to micron scale) by combining holographic lithography (top-down technique) and block copolymer self assembly (bottom-up method). The specific aims of the proposed research are: (1) Fabricating hierarchical nanostructures by combining holography lithography and block copolymer self-assembly, and (2) Using both homopolymer and block copolymers as the vehicle to introduce a variety of functional groups into the hierarchical nanostructure and fabricating multifunctional nanostructures for thermal sensitive optical switches, high density data storage, and porous membrane applications.

The proposed project, if successful, could lead to a new method to achieve hierarchical nanostructures for a variety of technological applications. The educational component of the proposal includes: (1) Developing a ?Polymeric Materials Enabled Nanomanufacturing? module that will be used in the ?Nanostructured Polymeric Materials? course. (2) Involving high school students and teachers, particularly under-represented populations, in the proposed research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dealing with the scale of one to a hundred nanometers, nanostructured materials and nano-technology have become an extremely active and vital area of research extending into almost every field of science and engineering. There are two categories of methods to manufacture nanostructured materials: top-down and bottom-up methods. The top-down method typically begins with a suitable starting material and then “sculpts” functionality from it. On the other hand, the bottom-up approach first forms the nanostructured building blocks, then assembles them into the final materials. Top-down method is approaching its theoretic limits and processes such as e-beam lithography are extremely costly. The feature size of most lithographic techniques is limited by the optical sources; a few tens of nanometer features are the limit. In contrast, starting from tailored molecules, bottom-up method can easily reach nanometer (even sub nanometer) feature sizes. One drawback of the bottom-up nanomanufacturing technique, however, is the difficulty to achieve large scale, defect-free structures; most of the self-assembled structures are on the micrometer scales. One of the most efficient methods to fabricate fascinating nanostructures is holographic polymerization or holographic lithography (H-L), which belongs to the top-down nanomanufacturing category. During the H-L process, a photopolymerizable syrup is exposed to two or more coherent laser beams, interference of which creates a standing wave pattern. This syrup can record the pattern, creating nanoscale, highly uniform structure with unique optic properties. Pure polymer films with a periodic refractive index modulation normal to the film surface (multiple layered film, reflection geometry) were first fabricated several decades ago and these subsequently formed the commercial basis for DuPont’s holographic component product line. This unique technique was extended in the mid-90’s by including low molar mass, anisotropic liquid crystal. Nanosized particles have also been patterned using this method.

In this NSF-supported project, we combined the top down holographic lithography and the bottom up block copolymer self assembly method to create ordered structure spanning length scales from a few nanometers to hundreds of nanometers. A number of soft matter including crystalline homopolymers, block copolymers and polymer electrolytes have been patterned into defect free nanostructures.  These nanostructures are also known as Bragg Reflectors – they can reflect certain color light. One interesting application would be using them as coating materials for pilots’ goggles so that the pilots’ eyes can be protected from laser weapons. More interestingly, we discovered that the color that this Bragg Reflector can reflect is also temperature-dependent – suggesting that we can use the coating as an in-situ temperature sensor and agile filters.  We believe that by combining these two nanomanufacturing techniques, the shortcomings of each method can be overcome: BCP self-assembly helps fabricate a finer structure that H-L cannot achieve while H-L renders long-range ordering of the BCP self assembled nanostructures.  Due to the fast kinetics of H-L, this hierarchical structure can be fabricated within a few seconds, which is viable for industrial applications.  

We also discovered that H-L patterned electrolytes can be achieved. Polymer electrolyte membranes with high ionic conductivity are important for energy-related applications, such as solid state batteries and fuel cells.  In order to achieve improved performance and longevity of the device, mechanical properties of the membrane must be promoted to the highest critical factor, particularly in solid-state lithium ion batteries.
